cwe_description: The software reads data past the end, or before the beginning, of an intended buffer. This can often lead to crashes or other faults that could be used to deny service to legitimate users. In some cases, it can also lead to the disclosure of sensitive information, or even arbitrary code execution if the read data is used to control program flow.
explanation: The code contains an out-of-bounds read vulnerability in the issuer parsing logic. Specifically, within the loop that extracts the issuer value, the condition `is->bv_len < x.bv_len` controls the loop, but the expression `is->bv_val[is->bv_len+1]` is accessed. When `is->bv_len` is equal to `x.bv_len - 1`, `is->bv_val[is->bv_len+1]` attempts to read one byte beyond the allocated buffer pointed to by `is->bv_val`, which is a substring of the input `in->bv_val` with length `x.bv_len`. This can lead to information disclosure, crashes, or other undefined behavior.

cwe_description: The software reads data past the end, or before the beginning, of an intended buffer. This can lead to crashes, information disclosure, or other undefined behavior.
explanation: The code contains an out-of-bounds read vulnerability in the issuer parsing logic. Within the loop that processes the issuer value, the condition `if ( is->bv_val[is->bv_len+1] == '"' )` attempts to access `is->bv_val` at an index one greater than the current `is->bv_len`. If `is->bv_len` is equal to `x.bv_len - 1` (the last valid character of the buffer pointed to by `is->bv_val`), then `is->bv_len+1` will access memory one byte beyond the allocated or intended buffer boundary. This can lead to a crash, information disclosure, or other unpredictable behavior.
